citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A rabbit (named “Pie”) became wounded in the groin by trauma of an unknown origin. The wound was not observed for at
least one week according to a facility representative. This wound became infested with maggots over an indeterminate
period of time, after which it was observed by a volunteer at the facility. After the wound was discovered, the facility
representative brought the rabbit to an emergency veterinary clinic the same day. According to the veterinarian’s
description of the wounds, they were deep and extensive. The rabbit was provided appropriate veterinary care at this time
and was euthanized. Each dealer and or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that
include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. Correct by
September 3, 2024.

The primary enclosures housing 9 rabbits have an excessive accumulation of fur, cobwebs, and general organic debris on
the wires. These materials prevent the proper cleaning and sanitization of the primary enclosures. Primary enclosures
shall be kept reasonably free of excreta, hair, cobwebs, and other debris by periodic cleaning. Correct by September 6,
2024.

An area of wire fencing in a pasture used for domestic hoofstock, llama, and alpacas has been damaged due to a mower
strike, with numerous sharp points exposed. The damaged wire was noted in the section of fencing that separates the two
areas of pasture. These sharp points can cause injury to the animals. Outdoor housing facilities shall be maintained in
good repair to protect the animals from injury. The facility must make repairs to or replace the damaged section of the
wire fence. Correct by September 17, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A rabbit (named “Pie”) became wounded in the groin by trauma of an unknown origin. The wound was not observed for at 
least one week according to a facility representative. This wound became infested with maggots over an indeterminate 
period of time, after which it was observed by a volunteer at the facility. After the wound was discovered, the facility 
representative brought the rabbit to an emergency veterinary clinic the same day. According to the veterinarian’s 
description of the wounds, they were deep and extensive. The rabbit was provided appropriate veterinary care at this time 
and was euthanized. Each dealer and or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that 
include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. Correct by 
September 3, 2024. 
3.56(a)(1) 
   
Sanitation. 
The primary enclosures housing 9 rabbits have an excessive accumulation of fur, cobwebs, and general organic debris on 
the wires. These materials prevent the proper cleaning and sanitization of the primary enclosures. Primary enclosures 
shall be kept reasonably free of excreta, hair, cobwebs, and other debris by periodic cleaning. Correct by September 6, 
2024. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
An area of wire fencing in a pasture used for domestic hoofstock, llama, and alpacas has been damaged due to a mower 
strike, with numerous sharp points exposed. The damaged wire was noted in the section of fencing that separates the two 
areas of pasture. These sharp points can cause injury to the animals. Outdoor housing facilities shall be maintained in 
good repair to protect the animals from injury. The facility must make repairs to or replace the damaged section of the 
wire fence. Correct by September 17, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
